reviewText: When I heard they were doing a remake of Battlestar Galactica, I was very interested.  But after seeing it, I'm sorry to say, I was very disappointed.  I really wanted to like this, but unfortunately, I just couldn't.There were a few things that I DID like about it, and I'll start off with those:1. Edward James Olmos as Adama -- simply genius!  He plays the role extremely well.2. The Colonel Tigh character.  He's a flawed human being, with a strong relationship and history with Adama.3. The attempt to make the show scientifically accurate.  I'd read that the space scenes would have no sound (as sound does not travel in the vacuum of space), but in the end, they fudged it a bit (you get *quiet* sound).But here's what I didn't like:1. It was too predictable, almost to the point of being cliched.2. Where are all the black people?  Don't we have enough problems with race in this country without having to revise two roles that were originally played by black men, with a white man and an asian woman?  I'm not trying to compare this to the original series, but for a show created in this day and age to not be diverse, well, it's kind of a shame (and just in case you're wondering, no, I'm not black).3. It feels like "Star Trek: The Next Generation" meets "Battlestar Galactica".  Very...sterile I guess.  I liked Star Trek: The Next Generation, but that's a completely different animal.  This isn't really surprising, as it was written by former Star Trek: The Next Generation scribe Ron Moore.  Which takes me to my next point...4. Character conflict for the sake of character conflict.  Ron Moore, while on Star Trek, worked under the Michael Piller premise of "Conflict between characters makes good drama".  Sure it does...if it's meaningful conflict.  If it's done just for the purpose of having none of the characters getting along, it's just dumb.5. Plot holes.  While I liked some of Ron Moore's Trek work, he's no stranger to plot holes.  Example: We learn that the human-looking cylon woman is one of only 12 made, yet at the very beginning of the film, a cylon just like her goes to the space station to meet the human diplomat, then the cylons destroy the station while she is on it.  What sense does that make?  Another example is the number of Battlestars: near the beginning, a tour guide on the Galactica says that there are 12, yet later it is mentioned that a larger number of them have been destroyed in the cylon attack.6. Baby killing.  Just...plain...unneccessary.7. It looks like Earth...around nowadays.  The costumes that are supposed to represent the culture of another (albeit human) planet look like modern Earth.  Are we on Caprica, or Lambertville, New Jersey?8. Starbuck.  Look, I'm not comparing this to the original, because even though I like the old show, I'd be just as happy with a modern remake/revisioning.  But having the Starbuck character be a woman was done for the sole purpose of making it a talking point.  During the opening, Starbuck is running around the Galactica and she passes Adama, who says "Hi Starbuck."  OH MY GOSH!  THAT'S STARBUCK?!?!  That was the whole point of it.  And not once in the remainder of the first part is she ever referred to as Starbuck again, but rather by her real name (Starbuck is her callsign).Anyway, even though I disliked it, a lot of people felt the opposite, so if you're interested, I'd say give it a shot.  Personally though, I felt it had a lot of problems.
summary: I wanted so bad to like this...

reviewText: This mini-series was something else!  Forget the campy 1970s one-season wonder, this drama -- and it is as much that as sci-fi -- totally reinvents the series and firmly places it into 21st century world events.  As you watch the story unfold it's hard not to draw parallels between the film's plot and the attacks of September 11, 2001, but it's not disrespectful or judgemental in any way shape or form.  As with most great science fiction, the reader/viewer is left to form their own opinions, make their own judgements (as it should be).  The casting of the characters to play the classic roles was also top-notch.  At first, I wasn't sure if Edward James Olmos was the right pick to play Commander Adama, but I turned out to be wrong.  His performances is spectacular and he serves as a dramtic center for the entire production, and the father-son dynamic between him and Apollo borders on Shakespearean.  Also great is Mary McDonnell as President Laura Roslin, the former Secretary of Education who is forced into the position of President.  Her character could easily be dismissed as the liberal foil to Adama's conservative militaristic style, but both characters surprise you in their willingness to change roles.  The rest of the cast is also great:  Jamie Bamber as Apollo, Katee Sackhoff as the "reimagined" Starbuck, Tricia Helfer as the seductive and menacing cylon in human form, the tough-as-nails, but tortured performance of Michael Hogan as Col. Tigh, and James Callas as Dr. Baltar -- the man who unwittingly helped bring about the downfall of mankind.  Also worth a mention are the great CGI effects.  The space battles are the best I've seen (either movies or television) and the "reimagined" cylons are very well done.  This movie will definately rankle purists who thought the campy 1970s TV show was sacrosanct, but if you're willing to give the show a try, Battlestar Galactica will win you over.  Moreover, if you haven't had a chance to watch the TV series, do so.  The drama and excitement has only improved.

reviewText: For many years I hoped that Richard Hatch would succeed in his hopes to resurrect the old "Battlestar Galactica" TV series, which I loved when I watched it on TV as a child.  I was very apprehensive upon hearing that the whole story was to be retold from the beginning.  My apprehension transformed to dread when I heard that Ron Moore was at the helm.  Moore was, after all, a former writing partner of Brannon Braga, one of the two men (the other is Rick Berman) who have done more to destroy "Star Trek", qualitywise, than any other people on earth.  After watching the new BSG miniseries, I was astounded at how well Moore's retelling turned out.Many others have focused on the gender changes to Starbuck and Boomer in their reviews.  There is no need for me to go into that here.  All I will say is that while I don't think that it was necessarily an actual improvement to change Boomer and Starbuck into women, it didn't hurt the story either, so I don't mind it.  Some of Moore's changes were most definite improvements.  I didn't notice this as a child when I first watched the show, but when I rewatched the original pilot episode as an adult, I did find it hard to swallow that the humans let their guard down so completely after a war that was as long and as bitter as the human-Cylon war was described as being.  Moore has changed it so that the weakness the Cylons exploit to strike their killing blow is not a frankly unbelievable level of naveté, gullibility, and wishful thinking on humankind's part, but rather a complacency born of decades without any contact.  This is far, far more believable.  I think the new take on Baltar is also an enormous improvement.  The old Baltar was simply hard to credit.  He tells the Cylon imperious leader that he wanted his colony subjugated under him rather than destroyed.  But strong though the desire for power is in some people, who could want it at such a price?  Benedict Arnold, Philippe Pétain, and Vidkun Quisling would look like heroes compared to a man who conspired to destroy eleven twelfths of humanity, in order to preside over the wreck of what's left as a Cylon puppet.  Who would want to be so remembered?  And who would want to live all his remaining days surrounded by people who, every last one of them, would hate him bitterly, no matter how obsequious they were to his face?  The new Baltar is far more believable.  Blinded by his own arrogance, he's duped into betraying mankind; he doesn't do it willingly.  Another improvement Moore made was to jettison the entire "casino planet" detour the original story took, again for reasons of credibility.  It just wasn't very believable that the pitiful remnants of humanity, starved, beaten, frightened, and desperate could so easily give themselves up to the delights of a big casino playground, and while there, seriously contemplate laying down their arms in the face of an enemy so obviously bent on their extinction.What might also be regarded as improvements are the changes made to the characters directed at making them more realistic and human.  As other reviewers have noted, the original BSG featured characters that were practically archetypes of both heroes and villians: Adama - wise, heroic father figure/leader; Apollo - noble young paladin; Starbuck - good hearted rogue; Baltar - oily, blackhearted villain with no redeeming qualities whatever, etc. etc..  The new BSG features characters that are not archetypes at all, but are just like real people.  They can be noble, brave, and heroic, true, but they can also be callous, unjust, and petty.  They display courage and heroism, but like real people, are also prone to prejudice, vindictiveness, pride, anger and every other sort of human flaw.  You never saw that in the old series' heroes.  I will not class this as an improvement, since I like stories that feature both sorts of characters.  And its interesting to look at this and see what's currently popular in our society.  The original BSG had archetypal characters probably because similar archetypal characters had been such a resounding success in "Star Wars".  And they were probably so well received in "Star Wars" because they came as a breath of fresh air to audiences who had been treated to over a decade of grittier, more flawed heroes (just take, for example, Clint Eastwood's character from "The Good, The Bad, and The Ugly"; he's almost the hero by default -- he's not a very good guy, he's just not as bad as the other two main characters).  And the more human heroes and downright anti-heroes of the the films of the sixties and seventies were a reaction to the archetypal heroes of the forties and fifties.  Now, with the new BSG featuring more realistic, flawed, and human heroes, the pendulum has swung back away from archetypes, but twenty years from now, it will probably swing back to them again.But the new "Battlestar Galactica", lacking the stainless heroes of the old version, is in many other ways just a better told story, and is overall an improvement on the original material.  I'm very glad the series has gone into production, and looks like it will be around for quite a while.  This miniseries was a great opening to it.
summary: Television sci fi at its best.

reviewText: I still have the old Battlestar Galactica toys in my toybox, and I was quite sceptical of attempts to "revive" this quarter-of-a-century old science fiction story. Much to my surprise, I enjoyed this mini-series much more than I expected to. Some critics have called it the spiritual successor to "Farscape", which I feel is a cheap analogy to make. Farscape still has that element of 'tap-dancing' to it - although it can get very dark at times, there's still a sense of daring and optimism that shines through (at least to me).Galactica is unremittingly dark, realistic and gritty. The characters have to make a lot of hard decisions - most notable of which is to leave a portion of the rag-tag fleet behind because they don't have FTL drives. This clearly shows that the new series will pull no punches.There are also some nice tributes to the old TV series. At the very beginning we get a glimpse of the old model Cylon robots, which were obviously from the Cyclon Uprising forty years ago. Baltar even describes them as "Chrome toasters". And the Colonial Viper makes a welcome return, when the entire fleet of upgraded vipers is shutdown by the Cylons during the initial attack. The new Battlestar Galactica is a more modern, slicker version than the original. We could very easily believe that at least some of the events in the original series occurred forty years before the current one began.But the biggest change (at least for me) between the Original Series and the new one, are the changes in the new characters. Commander Adama is much closer in character to Commander Cain from the original series - a driven, smart, but grim Military Commander. Colonel Tigh is an alcoholic, and for me at least, the least likeable character in the entire series. Of course, he's meant to be, so that's okay. Captain Lee Adama (callsign Apollo) is not the fully-blown hero that he was in the original series. The two biggest surprises are Starbuck and Gaius Baltar. Starbuck has the very first line in the mini-series, and I knew straight away she was going to be an intriguing character. I'm not entirely sure whether to pity Dr. Baltar or discombobulate him - his character isn't the outright villain that he was in the original, but he's not entirely a hero either. And he's quite possibly deranged.Another big change in this re-imagining of the series is the music, which takes some getting used to, even for someone who isn't a big fan of the original (which I am). In quiet moments, they're the suggestive chimes of percussive instruments. During the intense action sequences, we hear the compelling beat of tribal drums. And at the very end, we hear a tribal chorus. The music (at least for me) is "out-of-left-field", but totally appropriate for the new series.In conclusion, this new Battlestar series is a complete and total surprise. It's not just a re-imagining of an old (but much loved) Sci-Fi series. It's also the most serious high profile re-assessment of Science Fiction since Star Wars in 1977. Whereas both Star Wars and Battlestar Galactica were based on pulpy fifties SF, the new series is based on seventies literary Science fiction. Kudos to Ron Moore on a very successful, entertaining and thought-provoking revival of a much-loved TV series.
summary: Complex re-imagining of an old concept

reviewText: God, what a colossal disappointment this pile of garbage was!  Where do I begin?  Well, I could discuss what the producers got right (at least in pre-production).  I applaud their efforts to address some of the plot holes in the original series and make it more believable (for instance, having the colonies destroyed by nuclear holocost rather than laser cannons, which obviously would do minimal damage in the real world).  And I thought the CGI Cylons at the beginning were really cool.  I also thought it was cool to make the Cylon Raiders robot ships, because it really wouldn't make much sense to build a fighter to be piloted by robots when you could just make the ship itself a robot.Unfortunately, that's about all that they got right.  What they got wrong:The mood and atmosphere: it just didn't feel like I was watching Battlestar Galactica.  The most obvious shortcoming was the lack of the "Star Wars" inspired musical score.  Imagine watching "Star Wars" without John Williams.  The film would not have worked without his music.  And for me, BG doesn't work without the familiar soundtrack, either.  It had the same feel as "Dune" or "Farscape" or any other SciFi original series.Starbuck:  Who was the idiot who came up with the bright idea of making Starbuck a girl?  I think they should have showed a little more respect to Glen Larson before ruining the character he created.  Starbuck is a gambling, WOMANIZING hotshot pilot.  Period.  And it so happens, he was the BEST thing about the original series.  And if you're going to make such a radical change, at least give the audience a REASON for it. There should at least be a point behind it.  Don't be different just for the sake of being different.The space battles: Are you trying to be 2001 or are you trying to be Battlestar Galactica?  This is supposed to be a space opera.  We KNOW that fighters wouldn't manuever like airplanes in a vaccum.  We KNOW that there would be no sound when spaceships explode.  The point is, we DON'T CARE.  We want to see it because it looks and sounds cool.  We don't want realism.  We want to be entertained.Go out and buy the original series.  If you haven't seen this, don't bother.  Why spoil a perfectly good childhood memory?

reviewText: I guess I should start off this review by saying that I've never seen any part of the original Battlestar Galactica, so I cannot compare this to the original.  Having said that, I think that this miniseries was amazing; probably the best sci-fi I've seen since Firefly (and there are some similarities, such as the CGI effects, which were done by the same company).This is, for all intents and purposes, more of an extended pilot to a TV show rather than a complete miniseries, and it is an excellent beginning.  It begins with a textual prologue explaining how humans built the Cylons, which are large robots, for menial labor, but the Cylons eventually turned against their masters (big surprise).  There was a war, an armistice, and then 40 years of peace.  The Cylons were sent to live on a planet of their own, while humans remained on the 12 colonial planets (12 seems to be a recurring theme number in this, much like 47 on Alias).  But now, the Cylons are returning to the colonies to take them from humanity, and they have a new advantage: the Cylons now appear human.  There are 12 models, with limitless copies of each model.  Furthermore, they are essentially unkillable; when one body is destroyed, the conciousness of that particular copy is sent to another identical body.Meanwhile, the Battlestar Galactica, one of the 12 original Battlestars, is about to be decomissioned and turned into a museum, and its commanding officer, Commander William Adama (Edward James Olmos) is planning on retiring.  Things with the crew aren't so well either.  The XO, Colonel Tigh (Michael Hogon) is an alcoholic, Lt. Kara "Starbuck" Thrace (Katee Sackhoff) is a trouble-maker, and Adama's son, Lee "Apollo" Adama (Jamie Bamber) has just arrived, and he and his father have been avoiding each other since the death of Apollo's brother Zac.  In other parts of the galaxy, Secretary of Education Laura Roslin (Mary McDonnell), who is flying to the Galactica to oversee the decomissioning ceremony, has just been diagnosed with cancer.  Obviously, this is not a good time to be attacked.Unfortunately, this is exactly when the Cylons decide to begin the new war against humanity.  Unknowingly aided by Dr. Gaius Baltar (James Callis), who gave unrestricted access to the defense mainframe to model Number 6 (Tricia Helfer), the Cylons are able to simultaneously take out every significant human outpost, city, and ship, with the exception of the Galactica.  Rounding out the cast is Grace Park as Lt. Sharon "Boomer" Valerii.After an initial defeat, the humans try to rally together, only to be beaten back some more.  Things continue to get worse and worse for humanity, and there doesn't seem to be an end in sight.  Also, with the rest of the governing body gone, Secretary of Education Roslin, who was 42nd in line to become president, now holds that office.The special effects in this film are great.  As I said earlier, they were done by the same CGI company that worked on Firefly, and it is apparent that the style carried over (you can even see Serenity, the ship, in one scene).  There are pans, zooms, and shakes, as if someone were actually shooting the ships, as opposed to them being computer graphics.While the acting isn't great (though I've come to accept that from the Sci Fi channel), it isn't bad, and it's definitely a lot better than the acting on many shows that I've seen.Finally, one of the great things about this show (and also similar to Firefly) is that the show derives its greatness from the characters, not the effects or technology.  This is a story about the humans, and that is what makes it interesting.  It isn't focused on the tech (in fact, the Galactica is a very outdated ship), it centers on the human side of things, which is what good storytelling should do.After seeing this great beginning, I cannot wait to see where the weekly series takes us.

reviewText: When viewing this series it is important to remember that the vision for this new series was NOT to rehash old Battlestar episodes but to take a serious and dramatic look at what Sci Fi television could be.  If you are looking for actual human interactions as well as an attempt to develop actual plot hooks set in a Sci Fi setting, this may be what you are looking for.  If you want a FX extravaganza or an action series then look elsewhere.  Although the FX are exceptional and there are moments of action, the series does not rely on FX any more heavily than any other Sci Fi series might, and the emphasis is certainly not on non-stop action.Overall, the action is good, the realistic spin on the FX is great and acting is fair (certainly better than the majority of sadly performed Sci Fi that so intruiges some demographics).One warning:  the characters are not as you remember them 25ish years ago.  Enter with an open mind.

reviewText: Somehow, I expected genocide to be a little more exciting.Overall, the update to Battlestar Galactica (which I loved as an elementary schooler, even as I knew it wasn't as good as Star Wars, back before anyone insisted it was actually called A New Hope) works, and works very well. For all the crying about how Dirk Benedict's Starbuck character has been turned into a woman, it really ends up being a pretty smooth transition, at least in the miniseries. And that's the way the remake goes overall: Competent, clever, with a few new twists along the way, but not necessarily selling the total package.There are a few gaps in the storytelling -- who dropped a note in the commander's quarters without anyone spotting them, and how did they know what they knew? -- but not any worse than most television series.The only real knock against the BSG miniseries is how slow-paced it is. For a story telling of mankind being pushed to the edge of extinction in a matter of hours, it sure is casual about it. Other than one small mob (who were presumably waiting around in a field for a spaceship to land nearby) and some radio chatter, there's nothing to suggest panic or urgency. In a post-9/11 world, we know what people look like when shook up by a major trauma and fear of what comes next, and little of it shows up on the screen.Still, this is a strong basis for the new television series.Recommended for curious fans of the original or those looking for an antidote to the strong-jawed optimism of the Star Trek universe.
summary: A strong improvement on the original, but slow-paced

reviewText: Those of us who avidly watched and adored the original Battlestar Galactica were understandably nervous when signs began appearing in the mid to late 1990's that Galactica was going to return to the popular culture; either in a big or small screen incarnation.  Glen A. Larson had his ideas.  Richard Hatch had his ideas.  And the studio had its ideas.  And none of them could seem to agree on anything.  So much so that until the Sci-Fi Channel announced it was making the miniseries/pilot, many of assumed the project had been permanently shelved.Now, as the miniseries/pilot evolved, I was an absolute skeptic.  Rather than pick up where the original left off, it seemed that Sci-Fi was going to wipe the slate clean and re-tell the tale from scratch.  None of the original cast would appear in their original roles, much of the backstory would be fleshed out and/or altered in ways that would significantly change the flavor of the franchise, and most annoying to my mind, the show would feature a skinny, oversexed blonde bimbette making out with (apparently) a slick, Britishized Baltar."Great!"  I exploded one night, after seeing yet another overhyped preview.  "All we need is another science fiction series focusing entirely on some third-cut actress strutting around in questionable clothing!"  Star Trek gave us too much of that with 7 of 9 and, sadly, T'pol.  With former Trek man Ron Moore at the helm, I feared we were going to be treated to an Enterprise-ish disappointment.But I was not about to fall into the trap many other old-time Galactica fans had fallen into.  For all my concerns, I was determined to avoid hating the book before I'd even opened the cover.  Maybe the packaging looked crappy, but I'm old enough to remember how all the hard-core Star Trek people swore they'd hate and never watch Next Generation; and Next Generation is perhaps the seven best seasons of Star Trek to ever appear on the small screen.  Besides, Sci-Fi had Edward James Olmos onboard to play Adama.Adama.  The keystone character.  He carried the original franchise, thanks to Lorne, and he would most likely carry the new franchise, so the actor chosen to fill those shoes needed to be equal to the role.  And I thought Olmos was an excellent choice, as I have liked him in almost everything I have ever seen him in.  Joining him with be Mary McDonnell, another powerful veteran of the screen, buttressed by a bevy of younger actresses and actors, most of whome I had never seen, but if McDonnell and Olmos were hip to the project...So, I swallowed my reservations and watched the first two hours of the miniseries/pilot when it debuted.  And by the end of those two hours I was mightily impressed.  Nay, flabbergasted.  Sure the kinky Cylon bimbette was annoying, as expected.  But the writing was crisp, real, gritty, convincingly portrayed by a cast clearly devoted to making their characters as believable as possible.  Yes, this was not "my" Battlestar Galactica.  But that was OK because as much as I liked the original, seeing it again through adult eyes had shown me how kitschy and silly it often was.  The new series, even though it abandoned the original entirely, was being carried out deftly and with intensity.So I watched the second two hours, and at the end of it was totally sold.  Again, not "my" Galactica at all, but wonderfully enjoyable with very little to complain about.  Acting, great.  cript, great.  Special effects, top-notch.  The outer space shots and fight scenes were remarkably done and of a significantly different style from either Star Trek or Star Wars, making for a refreshing departure from the norm.  Overall, the pilot for the new Galactica showed a series that would be several levels more complex and more interesting than the original, and Olmos, McDonnell, and the rest had played their roles with absolute professionalism.I've gotten the miniseries on DVD and seen it several times since the television debut, and like it better each time.  I won't spoil the plot or tell-all where the story is concerned.  I'll just finish by saying that the new Galactica is perhaps the best, most serious, most solid science fiction television series I have seen in many, many years.  Maybe, ever! reviewText: This is dark science fiction at it's best.  Had this pilot been released as an epic movie it is doubtless that it would have effortlessly crossed the $150 million mark, at least in my view.  The stage is grand.  The Battlestar Galactica is due to be decomissioned and there is a large media coverage of this event.  At the same time a Cylon, in human female form and quite lovely, infiltrates the highest echelons of human military power and, essentially, designs the new human defense construct with built-in sabotage.  Needless to say, when the Cylons attack the twelve worlds no defense is put up against them and those human settlements are, for all intents and purposes, destroyed.First, the aspects of space flight are captured very well in this film and are far more authentic than anything seen in science fiction before or since.  Also, the weapons used are more like the results of human technology in our time period: nuclear warheads, hyperbullets, missile systems, and so forth.The WWIII like apocalypse leaves the Cylons as conquerors of the twelve worlds and the human race on the run and leaderless in the far reaches of space.Overall, this movie is thrilling and suspenseful.  The most horrible occurrence is the scene of a little girl on board a ship that has no escape from Cylon destroyers.  She is playing with her doll when the nuclear blast destroys the ship she is riding in.  It is a gut wrenching scene and it encapsulizes the terror that this film intended to evoke.  Had the writers worked to make this a major motion picture instead of a new TV pilot, it is likely that far greater horror could have been realized, so on that score I am disappointed that the story didn't reach the heights of emotion that was potential here.  Nevertheless, I give it 5 stars for being the most entertaining science fiction I've seen since The Terminator.Then there is the acting.  A nearly perfect cast is assembled for this one.  Edward James Olmos is flawless as Commander Adama.  You cannot ask for better sci-fi drama.If you haven't watched any of the new Battlestar Galactica, buy this and watch it.  If you're not hooked by the second hour then apparently it won't be for you.  But, I'd bet that you'll be a fan long before this film is over.  Moreover, it is far better to watch without all the commercial interruptions that took place when it first aired in 2003.

reviewText: While you're at it, could you be a little shiny metallic darling and put down the blaster?Look, I can keep this quick: what a relief! Galactica---a remake, a re-imagining, whatever you wanna call it, whatever: the show is delicious, gorgeous to behold, sleekly nasty, ominous & creepy, more than a little sad, and absolutely engrossing. If you're wondering whether or not to break down and pick it up, wonder no longer: just slate out a big block of time on your calendar to watch, because you're going to need it.When news leaked out in 2002 that Michael Rymer was at the helm of a supposedly sleek studio remake of the old Battlestar Galactica weekly series, there were convulsions of fear, loathing, and hatred throughout sci-fi Geekdom (I speak as a Geek, so don't get all itchy on me): Rymer was widely reviled for his hackwork on the pathetic "Queen of the Damned", a movie that crushed a massive amount of fan goodwill and was about as fun as popping your eyeballs out with a spoon.What atrocities would Rymer visit upon beloved old Galactica, the pulpy saga of a ragtag fleet of human refugees shepherded through the Galaxy's 'Injun Country' by a decrepit battleship? What horrors, what sick vileness, would he force upon the Cylons, those beloved killer trashcans?No worries there: under Rymer's direction and with Star Trek:TNG veteran writer Ron Moore at the helm, Galactica comes off just like the New Cylons: New! Improved! Shinier! Edgier! With 12 new models to choose from, all designed to mess with your pointy head and ruin your sh**!It's also uber-engaging and addictive, well written, distinctive, and astoundingly compulsive viewing. It almost makes me hate other, lesser, merely mortal series, for being everything but.Anyway: the Cylons, away doing other things (knitting, maybe, or blogging, no doubt) for some 40 years, decide to show up out of the blue and pay their respects to Humanity, scattered throughout the Twelve Colonies. Only the Cylons bring the gift that keeps on giving: Nukes. Humanity, taking a page from the old 21st century U.S. Democratic playbook, use harsh language. Humanity gets served up on a slab and put on the rails."The Rails" being the lumbering Battlestar Galactica, a hulk that, on the eve of the attack, is about to be mothballed as a museum. As it becomes clear that the Cylons are putting "think globally, act locally" into practice bigtime, the remnants of the military pull together to strike a desperate blow against their implacable enemy, and safeguard what remains of humanity.Now: cheesy special effects can kill something as fragile as spankin' new sci-fi, but Galactica's wizards sail beyond competent and achieve subtlety: the roar of battlestar cannons, the space-time-fabric-ripping hither and young of FTL starship transit, the manticore explosion of Cylon nukes---all of this is muted, blanketed, by the quiet howl of deep space. It's a nice touch, fitting, very much in keeping with the grim atmosphere.The other nice touch: hand-cam tracking shots that give the whole enterprise a kind of live-on-the-battlefield feel, a sort of fly-on-the-wall quality that proves totally immersive, whether you're in a fighter furball over the Galactica or in the red-lit war room.There's some jolly ensemble acting here, starting with Edward James Olmos. Olmos is a weird choice for Adama: he'll always be Blade Runner's Gaff to me, Gaff with his cheesy hat and dead eyes and origami animals. But it's a choice that works: Olmos does brooding, grizzled stoicism right up there with the best of them.Jamie Bamber ("Apollo") pulls his role together in a package with far less preen & pout than I feared when I saw the actor, with his chiseled, but weak features; Katie Sackhoff serves up a Lt. Starbuck with a side of cigar-chomping & poker-sharking, drop an X-chromosome, please: she's got the weird Dirk Benedict eye-thing down pat, and (I honestly don't know why) she's just as lushly fun to watch as Tricia Helfer.Tricia Helfer...Let's talk about her for a second.The Cylons were also listening to customer feedback, like "Less tin! less sharp spikey pointy things! Kinder! Gentler! Nubiler!", and so they also gave the Other Gift that Keeps on Giving, Cylon Model #6 (the utterly delicious, adorable, mouth-wateringly gape-provokingly gorgeous Tricia Helfer), who jets down to Caprica on the 9:10 shuttle and sets up digs with Galactica's answer to Bill Gates, Dr. Gaius Baltar(the amusingly tortured James Callis), sinking those shiny, sexy pinions into Baltar but keeping her eyes on the real prize: full access to the Colonial Defense Network computer. By your Command, indeed.The weakest link here is Mary McDonnell as Laura Roslin,the Education chief who reluctantly (at least that's what we're supposed to believe, but Roslin is practically shoving corpses over to get the top job after the massacre) takes the reins as the Colonial President.I've never been a McDonnell fan: it's that constant smirking self-superior preciousness she brings to her parts, as if she knows some big hairy secret nobody else is privy to, and here it's on display, front and center. I wanted somebody, anybody, a Cylon maybe, to tear her head off and take a steaming Cylon dump down her neckhole.But that's a small turd in an otherwise big old happy punchbowl, and Battlestar Galactica Season 1 has played a strong first hand: this is Space Opera, done right.JSG

reviewText: Although this has been out for awhile I just watched it for the first time through Amazon Prime (it's free if you are a prime member). reviewText: First things first: This is included in the first season DVD set, so, unless you are a collector or only interested in the miniseries version, get season 1 instead.Now...I won't get into too many details here, as I do not wish to spoil the story line for those who haven't seen this yet. The ship has been redesigned to more clearly present itself as a warship, sort of along the lines of what I imagine a space based aircraft carrier might look like.  The new fighters are also quite modern looking, but are eventually dropped in favor of the original fighters as part of the story line.  Other ships are modernized as well for this series, making the story far more believable than the original series was.Galactica's crew is also modernized, with both men and women fully integrated.  Uniforms are far more militaristic, and weapons are clearly not toys.  Interpersonal relationships are also more realistic, complete with fraternization, insubordination, and so forth.  This series essentially kills the premise that men and women can't fight along side each other, at least within the fictional modern society.The Cylons, as would be expected, are also far more modern.  While the Centurions retain certain aspects from the original series, they also are modernized and far more threatening in appearance, I suspect largely due to such movies as Terminator.  The effect is far more realistic, from the design to how they move and operate.  However, this model will play only a small role in the series, as the truly modernized Cylon soldier appears very human not just in appearance, but in how they behave.  Cylon base stars and fighters are also modernized as well, in ways I can't get into here without spoling future episodes for you.Weapons systems for both sides of the conflict have much more in common with today's real world capabilities than, say, Star Trek.  Gone are the laser cannons and phasers, and back are bullets, shells, missles, and nuclear warheads.  The only unrealistic aspect of this change is the ability of Galactica to survive a direct hit from a nuke, which is never explained in the story.All ships are also equipped with "FTL Drives," which allow Cylons and Colonials to "jump" between different locations to escape or attack one another.  This is far more realistic, from a story line point of view, than the original series, which allowed slow moving ships to escape other slow moving ships that somehow magically seemed to catch up.  To add to the realistic feel of this device, the story shows that careful planning and timing are necessary for the FTL drive to operate correctly.Now for the story line...Essentially, it is 40 years later.  The Cylons and Colonials have a sort of armistice, in which the two sides have withdrawn from each other and have gone their separate ways.  The existance of Cylons is finally explained.  Seems humans created the Cylons as a sort of labor force, and as is inevitable in such stories, the Cylons had rebelled against their "masters" when they gained self-awareness.  This provides a link to the previous series, not to mention a far more reasonable explaination for the origines of the conflict.An outpost between the Colonies and the Cylons was established to allow the two sides to meet annually, should they choose to, to discuss issues of mutual interest.  During the previous 40 years, the Cylons have never shown up.  That changes, of course, and the war breaks out during that one meeting.After that, the story line is very similar to the original, albeit with the twist of Cylons looking and acting very human.  The Cylons destroy the colonies, and they go in search of a mythical thirteenth colony called Earth.  The battles are spectacular and far more realistic for a space battle with conventional weapons, save for the effects of the nuclear weapons on the various ships.  Colonials are polytheistic, significant in later episodes, while the Cylons are monotheistic, somewhat confusing given they acknowledge that humans created them.  This aspect becomes very important in later episodes, although I suspect it will have religious extremist viewers coming unglued.The casting is brilliant, as are the individual performances.  Those who have objected to the casting of women in the roles of Starbuck and Boomer need to get over themselves, as the characters are very integral to future episodes.The graphics and special effects are equally stunning, and the set designs are pure genius.All in all, the series is brilliantly done.  Even those who do not typically like the genre will enjoy this series, and will look forward to future episodes as well.

reviewText: Before I go into my review, I first have to say that I've never shown any interest in watching Battlestar Galactica.  I've never seen the original series from the 70's, nor have I seen the new one.  I always had this preconceived notion in my mind that BSG was "just another Star Trek rip-off."  Coming from a die-hard Trek fan, it would make sense for someone to have that opinion.  I'll just say that after watching this miniseries/prequel, I'm now hooked!BSG Miniseries plays like an epic movie.  I love how they expertly portrayed the start of what seems like utter chaos and war that will eventually spread out over the main series.  The Colonials (humans) vs. the Cylons (robots) is a classically epic battle, for sure.  It really reminds me a lot about the Borg from Star Trek (and the Daleks from the Dr. Who series).  Clearly, BSG has borrowed from earlier series, but that's not a bad thing here.What's interesting is how the Cylons are portrayed.  They were created by humans that eventually turned against their masters.  In other words, humans created such an advanced and sophisticated technology that it is now being used to their detriment.  I think this very concept holds prophetically true for what's going on in our current society with all these gadgets, smartphones, etc.  One day, I have a very strong feeling that this will happen to us.  There's no question in my mind about that.  Right now, our technology is affecting us from an intraspecies perspective.  It is substantially decreasing our ability to communicate on an interpersonal level.  The very basics of human communication and relating are being eroded.  That is a fact.  This erosion will continue for some time until humans have created an independent, artificial life form capable of doing everything that we humans do.  Then that life form will rebel, etc. etc. etc.  This is prophecy, folks!!!Aside from all that, the acting is great here, too.  I've never seen so many last-minute, edge-of-your-seat, morally and ethically challenged decisions being made in a single sci-fi movie or miniseries.  Some of the decisions made in this movie really leave you stunned and asking yourself "what if they did this instead?"  Great stuff!  My favorite character is the blond rebel fighter pilot chick.  So hot...But anyway...I highly recommend everyone to watch this 3-hour film, even if you're not sci-fi fans.  You'll definitely find something to appreciate, and it will make you THINK.

reviewText: "Professional" is the word that kept popping up in my head when I was watching this, as the original series (which hasn't really aged that well) was thrown together rather hastily to capitalize on the success of STAR WARS.  Instead of Greco-Egyptian-themed space opera, the new series is an America-esque gritty, dark spaceborne Navy technothriller-type docudrama, where the uniforms look like uniforms rather than pajamas, the cameras recording it all actually exist (a piece of debris from a destroyed space station sends it spinning in the opening) and the old Colonial warriors' names have become fighter pilot call signs ("starbucking" seems to be slang for drunk & disorderly conduct, and Boomer's landings are so loud and bad you can hear them down in the hangar bay even through hard vacuum).  You can even forgive Baltar this time around for selling out humanity, as he's now a horndog scientist who thinks more with his libido and the Cylons now have human-looking infiltrators that come in a Victoria's Secret Lingerie Model variant that seduces him.  In addition to introducing new characters, everyone from the original series has gotten a humanizing makeover: Adama's a quiet brooder who only yells to motivate the crew, Tigh's a functional alcoholic, Zak's offscreen death was the result of pilot error due to lack of talent, Apollo's furious about Zak being pushed into the military because of that lack of talent, Starbuck's antics seem to be penance or panacaea for getting Zak killed because she was dating him, and Boomer's a rookie recon pilot sleeping with the head of aerospacecraft maintenance.  The simple fact that the new show got renewed says a lot about its improvements over the original.

reviewText: What long-time "Star Trek" writer and producer Ronald D. Moore has accomplished with "Battlestar Galactica (2003 Miniseries)" is more along of the lines of what Harlan Ellison had originally hoped for in his original script for the original series "Star Trek" episode "City on the Edge of Forever"; a gripping, quite realistic, and moralistic, science fiction tale. Although I did like Glen Larson's original concept for "Battlestar Galactica", Moore has made a much more interesting, and exciting revision, that features some of the finest space battles and military conduct under enemy fire ever shown on a space opera science fiction television series (Here its only equal is the equally brilliantly imagined and realized "Babylon 5", though the latter still ranks as my favorite candidate for finest science fiction television series ever made, thanks to series creator J. Michael Straczynski's excellent writing as well as this series' wonderful cast.). Gone are the ancient Greek and Egyptian-styled ceremonial robes and fighter pilot helmets, replaced by far more professional military officers and sailors who could find themselves at home on a real-life US Navy aircraft carrier or aboard one of EarthForce's ("Babylon 5") destroyers and heavy cruisers, with a gritty realism that comes straight out of "Black Hawk Down" and ample doses of suspense worthy of "Run Silent, Run Deep" or the two best episodes of "Star Trek: The Next Generation" ("Best of Both Worlds", Parts I and II)  which have the 24th Century USS Enterprise and its crew pitted against the Borg led by a Borg-assimilated Captain Jean-Luc Picard. I saw the NBC-edited version of the miniseries last night, and it holds up quite well, which is why I think that this may be the best pilot ever conceived, written, directed and acted for a science fiction television series.Veteran actor Edward James Olmos leads this excellent cast as Commander William "Husker" Adama, the commander of the soon-to-be decommissioned Battlestar Galactica, who will soon find himself matching wits with newly sworned-in Colonial President Laura Roslin (Mary McDonnell), the surviving senior figure in the Colonial government (43rd in the line of succession); together they must lead the human survivors from the deadly Cylon fleet. Jamie Bamber plays his surviving son, Captain Lee "Apollo" Adama, one of the battlestar's senior Viper fighter pilots. Katee Sackhoff is Lieutenant Kara "Starbuck" Thrace (a controversial casting move, but one that really works quite well thanks to Sackhoff's fine acting), a rowdy, fun-loving ace Viper pilot who strongly dislikes those in authority, especially the battlestar's alcoholic XO, Colonel Saul Tigh (Michael Hogan); and yet she is treated by Commander Adama as the daughter he never had, since she was the fiance of his younger son Zack, killed in a Colonial Viper training accident. James Callis is Gaius Baltar, the brilliant Colonial scientist who inadvertently gives the Cylons the keys to the Colonial defense grid, ensuring the success of their devestating, genocidal attack on the Twelve Colonies, through his synthetic human Cylon lover Number Six (Tricia Helfer). And rounding out this cast are Grace Park (Lieutenant Sharon 'Boomer' Valerii) and Aaron Douglas (Chief Petty Officer Tyrol).In Moore's revision, the Cylons are not the mechanical descendants of an alien reptilian race, but instead, the former robotic servants of the twelve human colonies (I was impressed with their new appearances as both robots and synthetic humans like Number Six.). Forty years after fleeing human space, they return, launching a genocidal nuclear attack against the colonies (It is an attack which Moore, himself, has admitted elsewhere, was influenced by the 9/11/01 Al Qaeda terrorist attacks on the United States; for example, instead of seeing battlestars exploding, we watch mushroom nuclear clouds rising high above the surface of the planet Caprica.), and wiping out the entire Colonial battlestar fleet, except for the old Galactica. Only a ragtag fleet of 50,000 humans aboard a motley collection of FTL civilian ships and the aging Battlestar Galactica survive, searching for a mythical lost colony, "Earth", which may, or may not, exist. To his credit, Moore offers a more racially diverse view of humanity than was present on Larson's original series, which is reflected both amongst the civilians and the crew of Battlestar Galactica. What I saw last night was three hours of the most exciting science fiction ever shown on national television; the DVD set includes the cuts which were made due to the mature nature of their contents. Fans of the original series should recognize Moore's important contribution in reviving the fortunes of "Battlestar Galactica" and raising its stature from Grade C television entertainment to high quality cinematic science fiction.
summary: Best Pilot for a Science Fiction Television Series Ever

reviewText: When they decided to remake this series, they did it right.  The twelve human colonies have recovered from their war with the Cylons, mechanical beings created to make life easier.  The Cylons have gone off to new pastures and have not been heard from in forty years.  The Battlestar Galactica, the last remaining Battlestar from the original war is about to be decommissioned and turned into a museum.  It is during the decommissioning ceremonies that the Cylons make their return known.  They can now look like us and managed to catch the human worlds with their pants down.Things get tense as Commander Adama finds himself the senior officer in the fleet and the Secretary of Education finds herself accepting the office of the presidency.  As the surviving humans band together, styles clash between the two leaders.  In the end it is decided to look for the mythical thirteenth colony on Earth.  This is the hope that will bind the refugees together during the series.I was very impressed.  I had caught part of the series on television and decide to give the mini-series a try.  The acting, plotting and visuals are all so far above the original it is almost a crime to compare them.  But my recommendation is not to buy this because the mini-series is included in the Season One collection.  There is no reason to buy it separately (wish I had known that).  If you like action and drama that is aimed at a thinking adult audience, then this is a show for you.

reviewText: Let me first state that I was very young when the original "Battlestar Galactica" was born on television.  My fondest memories of that show are of reading the huge comic adaptation that my older brother was kind enough to let me have and of the "Starbuck" and "Cylon" action figures that I had.  I have recently started watching the original series on SciFi Channel and completely fell back in love with it.  For its time, it was an amazing and fun show.  The special effects still hold up pretty good as well, considering how old the series is.Now to the new, "re-imagined" version of "Battlestar Galactica."  I really enjoyed this miniseries when it first played on SciFi Channel.  It has a number of differences that make it just as good or better than the original in some aspects, but the original series will always hold a special place in my heart.The characters may have the same names as the original ones, but that's about the only true similarities between them.  As everybody already knows, Starbuck is now portrayed by Katee Sackhoff, a woman.  I have no problem with this whatsoever.  Yes, I loved Dirk Benedict as Starbuck and he will probably always be the true Starbuck to me, but Ms. Sackhoff does a pretty good job in this role.  I'll agree with another reviewer that Sackhoff starts off too over-the-top, but sinks comfortably into the role as the movie plays out.  Edward James Olmos is solid as Adama, and it will be interesting to see how often he and Mary McDonnell's character butt heads on decisions as the series starts its run.  Apollo comes across as the perfect "son rebelling against father" type. Of course, along with the "Starbuck" scandal, the fact that Col. Tigh and Boomer are no longer black characters has also caused a stir.  Grace Park does a good job as Boomer.  She gives the character an innocence that wasn't present in the original character.  Michael Hogan plays Col. Tigh.  Col. Tigh is wishy-washy and nearly drunk most of the time, which is a nice change from the original Tigh.  His character is full of emotion in this film, especially when Adama hands over a crucial decision to him to decide upon. The rest of the cast does extremely well.  When compared to other SciFi Channel flicks, they would all win awards for their performances.The Cylons have also been overhauled for this new series.  In all, there are twelve different models, all serving a different purpose.  The model with the most exposure(figuratively and literally) in this miniseries is the Number Six model.  Number Six(played by a Victoria's Secret model, really) seduces Dr. Baltar and tricks him into giving her access to some very important information that aids the Cylon cause in destroying humanity.  No. Six will not remind you of any of the old school Cylons out there.  She's a very attractive, very evil humanoid-looking robot.  Her character is given a few rather choice scenes, my favorite being when she encounters a newborn baby.  I won't spoil anything, but just prepare yourself for some very wicked acts from her character.  Homage is paid to the original Cylons if you look quickly during a scene in one of the Galactica's hangars, which is converted into a gift shop.  We are given a glimpse of some of the other models in the movie as well, but hopefully they will play a larger role in the series as it develops.As far as special effects are concerned, this is the best I've ever seen from SciFi Channel.  They are nearly flawless.  They are heavy on CGI, but are very enjoyable to watch.  I also enjoyed the handheld camera scenes of the space battles.  The Vipers, Raptors, and Cylon ships look very realistic and move more like a "real" starfighter would in my opinion.  Sound is minimal during the dogfights, 'cause in space, no one can hear you scream.The DVD is pretty thin on extras, so if that's your thing, you may just want to watch this when it's on SciFi Channel.  If you're like me, however, you'll want this for your library because it is a very exceptional show.  The highlight of few extras included is "The Lowdown," which goes a little in depth on the creation of the miniseries.Look beyond the old "Galactica," and view this version as something completely different and new.  I think that once you get beyond some of the major changes(Starbuck, sexy Cylons, etc.), you'll be able to see that this is really a good movie and if the series is anything like it, I'm sure it will be around for a very long time.
summary: Solid Groundwork For What Appears To Be A Good Series

reviewText: Important note: As I understand it, the 'Season 1' box set containsthis mini-series that started the whole thing off.  If true, youdo NOT need this if you but 'Season 1'One of my favorite television series of all time along with 'The Wire'and 'Breaking Bad'.Like 'The Wire' this is a complex, Dickensian study of human nature,not afraid of asking big questions, and meticulously plotted like agreat novel, so that each episode is a chapter in a much larger whole.Just as 'The Wire' used the overly familiar cliché' world of the copshow to jump off from and shatter our preconceptions, and 'BattlestarGalactica' uses the sci-fi series, and the idea of human versus robotwars the same way.This is thinking person's sci fi, in the tradition of Arthur C. Clarke,or Isaac Asimov. It's about why we are how we are, what it means to bea human being, morality under constant pressure in times of war,fathers and sons, impossible loves, metaphors for modern and recentpolitics and real world situations.My wife, far from a sci-fi fan was hooked after 3 episodes, and we torethrough 5 years of shows in just a few days. It's that addicting.The acting is all at least quite good, and some cast members areremarkable, creating characters full of depth, complexity andcontradiction. The writing is terrific, allowing the characters tochange and grow, but always in ways that make sense, creating seeminglyinexplicable conundrums, only to find surprising, sometimes shocking -but ultimately logical and satisfying - ways to explain where they'vetaken us. The special effects are generally very impressive for TV,even if they're not really why you watch this show.It also has some of the most tense episodes of television I've everseen, and some of the season enders left me completely wrung out andblown away. I was sad to get to the last episode, just as one is sad tofinish a great book.

reviewText: Okay, first of all, I'm not a purist. I don't mind a new Battlestar Galactica series being made. I don't mind that it's a re-do. What I do mind is them changing EVERYTHING! I despise that their names are "handles", not their real names. But even THAT I can tolerate.What I can't tolerate is bad Sci Fi. And this new BS is exactly that. Who knew that Caprica had a 24 hour day, that it has the same rotation as the Earth around the same kind of sun at the same distance from their sun? (The wall clock on the President's ship - and 12 hour clock with hands - certainly indicates this!) Who knew that the twelve colonies evolved EXACTLY like Earth, right down to the fashion of suits and neckties for the men, pantsuits and skirts for the women (civilian, I mean)? Who knew that they kept an old Earth-style 1970s 8-track tape player in the weapons storage room? (Next time you see a rerun in which "Boomer" is getting some explosives from the weapon's room, look in the background on the left - it's there!) And what kind of advanced society, like the twelve colonies are supposed to be, has lazer cannons for their Vipers but have to resort to projectile weapons for their hand weapons?Okay, so the crew of the original (and only, in my opinion) Battlestar Galactica had big hair. Big deal! It's good Sci Fi! I admit Muffit the Daggit and Boxey are annoying at times, but the stories were good, even if the budget forced them to use the same special effects over and over again. But you have to remember the time period when the first one came on air! Serious Sci Fi television was considered a no-no (television execs still thought of Sci Fi as kiddie shows, like Lost in Space). So, just ignore the big hair. Ignore the cute doggey that the executives at ABC had forced them to put in to gain the attention of their targetted audience, a.k.a. children. Ignore the repeated special effects that the producers of BS had to use because of budget. Just watch the show for stories and you'll be enjoying great Sci Fi.As opposed to this in one eye, out one ear crap.

reviewText: The original "Battlestar Galactica" was never great television science fiction when it came out in 1978.  In the wake of the phenomenal success of "Star Wars" we were grateful to have a science fiction series on television.  Unfortunately the producers of the movie sued ABC and even though the series cost a million dollars per hour it only last a single season and basically by the end the only ones watching were kids (and me, who likes to watch shows go all the way down until they crash on the deck).  The less said about the wretched "Galactica 1980" the better (I apologize for even mentioning it).Consequently, I have no problems with Ronald D. Moore (writer on three "Star Trek" series, two "Star Trek" movies, and "Roswell") and Christopher Eric James (first and only screen credit to date) doing some radical revisions of Glen A. Larson's original teleplay.  Just ditching Muffit the mechanical daggit is a pretty good start, but basically what we have with this "remake" is more of a reconceptualization.  What remains the same is that in a galaxy far, far away the humans are just about wiped out by the Cylons, who are mechanical creatures.  The Battlestar Galactica is the only one of the battlestars in the fleet of the 12 Colonies left after the assault, and with a rag-tag fleet of civilian vessels the Galactica heads off in search of the fabled lost 13th colony known as "Earth."The major changes are in terms of the characters, most of whom have been seriously revamped for the 2003 mini-series and the series (which starts tonight).  The most notable change is that Starbuck, the best pilot in the galaxy, is now a female character (Katee Sackhoff), so that Dirk Benedict's reputation for playing a second-rate Han Solo is now still secure.  That this is the biggest change is really something because the Cylons are no longer metal soldiers but rather synthetic humans who are apparently cloned or whatever in "Terminator" fashion (so we get a bunch of copies of a few "models").  Then there is the fact that since Starbuck is now the female Lt. Kara Thrace (as is Boomer: insert your own inappropriate comment here) there is the possibility of romance with Captain Lee "Apollo" Adama (Jamie Bamber), which could take the revisionism here to a whole new level.  Finally, the human traitor has been changed from a consummate scene-stealer like John Colicos as Lord Baltar to the cowardly genius, Dr. Gaius Baltar (James Callis), who has a neural clone (ala "Farscape") so that he can have meaningful conversations with the sexy Number 6 (Tricia Helfer), one of those synthetic Cylons.  This could well be the biggest change of them all, but we shall have to see how it plays out.The biggest problem with this mini-series is that the big problem--to wit, THE END OF THE WORLD (well, 12 worlds)--keeps taking a back seat to the interpersonal problems of the characters.  For example, Adama and Apollo are estranged because of the death of Adama's other son and Starbuck is butting heads with the Gallactica's E.O. Colonel Tigh (Michael Hogan).  Then there is the new President of the 12 Colonies, Laura Roslin (Mary McDonnell), who is trying to exert civilian control over the military and deal with having just learned she has terminal cancer.  All this will matter down the road in the new series, but but it doesn't take much to see that the problems of a bunch little people don't amount to a hill of beans in a crazy world where the Cylons have reduced the population of the 12 colonies to 50,000 civilians.  But some people have trouble noticing this until the last act of the mini-series.Beyond the major conflict, which is the fact the Cylons are killing all of the human beings they can find, and the big new plot twist, that the Cylons can now pass as human beings, the pivotal crisis in the mini-series is between Commander Adama and President Roslin.  He wants to get his battlestar refitted and go attack the Cylons.  She insists that the war is over, humanity is lost, and the only intelligent thing to do is to get far, far away, really, really fast.  For some reason, this does not make sense to Adama.  There is no notion that he is extremely bloodthirsty (or suicidal), so his position seems contrived (or stupid).  Even worse, the screenplay dictates that he change his mind after witnessing a small moment of people just being people.  Then, instead of wanting to attack all the Cylon vessels in the universe, he decides that making babies would be a better tactical approach.The result is that having hired Edward James Olomos to give the new Adama even more gravity that did Lorne Greene (who did have that great shock of white hair and the deep voice), they contrive to keep his character in low gear until the end of the four-hour mini-series.  Then the character suddenly emerges from his stupor, gives a big speech, tells a tremendous lie, and sets up the series to come.  But until that point it is McDonnell's President Roslin who is the voice of rational (if shaky) authority, and if you really pay attention you will see that as a general rule the women are a lot smarter than the men this time around.  More importantly, the women are the ones who really get the point that they have lost the war, and it is when the focus is on the disaster and not the people that "Battlestar Galactica" works best.The special effects are pretty good, especially compared to what John Dykstra did way back when, and as long as the characters are too busy fighting and avoiding being killed to bicker which other there are some good moments here.  It is because of the special effects that I rounded up in the end on this one.  I still like the basic idea of the last members of humanity fleeing their home galaxy to find a new place to live.  This is decidedly different from "Star Trek: Voyager" and certainly makes a lot more sense than "Space: 1999."  Besides, all of the camp elements from the original are gone, and that is the best news of all.  Hopefully when we watch the series all that will really matter from the mini-series is the basic situation and not the strained interpersonal dynamics.  We shall see.

reviewText: Ten years after Star Trek was cancelled, BG was launched and immediately became its own cult phenomenon. The series benefitted from more advanced special effects technology (John Dykstra of Star Wars fame headed that up), and a solid cast of actors including Lorne Greene, John Colicos (who starred as evil Klingon commander Koor in one Star Trek episode), Richard Hatch, and Dirk Benedict.The gigantic Battlestars and the Egyptian themed fighters were cool, and the Cylons were the implaccable robotic bad guys out to exterminate the rag-tag remnants of humanity. This being prime time and the bland, disco-dancing 70s, the TV censors forbade the Cylons actually killing any human pilots, and so the closest our intrepid Starbuck and the other pilots ever came to perdition was getting his vertical stabilizer singed, but that's okay. The dogfights were still well done and the dramatic launching tubes were a nice touch, too. They tended to reuse some of the special effects to cut costs, but what the hell, that makes BG no different from Star Trek in which the same phasor shot from the Enterprise in space was reused a number of times.Although the show never achieved the large fandom of Star Trek, the fan base of the show is as loyal as any series ever aired, many of whom prefer it to Star Trek. That's quite a testamonial to a series that only ran for a year before being cancelled.Now with this miniseries, the show returns with all the drama and originality of the first episodes. Experienced viewers will note some changes (Starbuck is now a woman), but overall, the new serial is true to the original. The special effects are even better, the casting is great, and the stories even more intense and taught. There seems hardly a moment in each episode where you can catch your breath and relax before the next disaster strikes. Overall I think this is a fine series and a credit to the original, much loved show.

reviewText: The original series will always be a classic because, well, it was the original.  That said, if they had the technology (and perhaps the less stringent FCC rules regaurding risque) I can only wonder how the two versions would compare.  The old series was strictly fantasy that started off with an epic quality but quickly desolved into episodic rehash that was probably good for the time, but is not something I'd go out of my way to watch in reruns. The new series pilot is definitely more sophisticated, both in plot, themes, and technology, as well as being a bit more current topicwise.  I can't fully say that I like the reconstitution of the basic premises but I for one think that dispite some of the cliche bits, it was on the whole well conceived and well executed.I give full kudos to the new miniseries for bringing a very classy hat tip to the old series; in the display of the all too familiar machine relics, the museum music, and especially the integration of the old style Vipers into the new series in a way that was very pertinent to the story.  And I give full props for having the guts to go against the grain of die-hard fans and deviate so drastically from the original series, and not just for the sake of distinction but with an obviously thought-through script.The highlights for me are: 1) Baltar is now more complex and in some ways sympathetic character who was a victim of his own ego rather than the simple maniacal villain with motives that were never explained. 2) Olmos brings every bit as much respect and gravitas to the show as Lorne Greene did (MacDonald was a great surprise too).  3) Updated space combat with subdued sound fx and more realistic action (not planes in space) were pretty. The sneak attack/invasion used a nice plot gimmick. 4) I like that the Galactica was a relic slated for museumhood rather than the much vaulted flagship that one would expect... and that fact was also pertinent to the plot.The rest I was neutral about and either accept or forgive.  The gender changes didn't bother me, in fact some were done very nicely. I'll miss the original Starbuck's smarminess versus the new one's brashness, but she did a good job in the role.  I don't appreciate gratuitous sex-related scenes, but at least there was some point to #6's relationship with Baltar. Perfectly human robots in general are a bit cliche but I don't see a way around it here. The new tensions between characters (e.g. the XO and Starbuck) are contrived but don't hurt.  The feel-good world-tribal thematic music didn't have the majestic quality I would have expected but wasn't bad.  Overall, I very much enjoyed the miniseries pilot.  If I had only one pet peeve it would probably be the over-use of the zoom-cam effect, but it hardly ruined an otherwise refreshing bit of sci-fi.  It was a great starting point for the upcoming series.
summary: A risky remake that exceeded expectations.

reviewText: The reviews for this like most other SCi-Fi shows these days are completely mixed and random.  You get a bunch of viewers complaining about everything and trashing it and then you have the pre-programmed "We love it" robots reviewing it.  So, the right thing to do is to view the show and use your OWN judgement.  I did.This is a pretty solid show and obviously someone put some thought into it. There are plenty of good characters I like the way each separate situation unfolds.  Noone gets too much screen time, things roll along and the pacing is about perfect for a drama-based Space Show. The special effects are top notch for a TV show and probably even for decent movie. This show uses REAL actors and people with some experience instead of unknown nobodys. Its amazing how different it is when real actors are used for a show like this.  The sets are good looking and the environments are well displayed. It is apparent that although the budget was not unlimited they certainly had a pretty big cash stash to use.  Here are my Hits and Misses for this show:HITS / THE GOOD:- Real actors gave the show a credibility that most like it do NOT have.- The character of Gauis is very interesting, dealing with his own desires and "bad boy" image and feeling guilty for potantially causing a BIG mess. Very cool!- Enough plot twists and surprises to keep you saying "ahhhh" without getting over-done like M Night Shayalman movies.- Some refereneces to vintage BSG like the Vipers and Launch Bays.- Fairly intelligent science and character actions. No leaps of faith regarding behavior or actions taken.- Edward Olmos as Adama was a great choice, he played that part just about perfectly.- Good special effects and sets.MISSES / NOT SO GOOD:- Starbuck is now an obnoxious chick that I want to throw in a wood shredder. I can get past her.... but uggggh!- Camera work during battle scenes needs to be more panoramic and less jittery. Some space shots were hard to follow and had me refocusing my eyeballs to see what the heck just flew by!- Not enough actual war scenes. A few cool bomb clouds and light flashes but thats it. An attack of this magnatude needed to be shown much more in-depth. Lets see the suffering, see ther carnage. Alls you hear is that "We lost this city, that ship, etc, etc."  WAY too under-dramatic for me.- Nuclear weapons seem pretty antiquated for High-tech Cylons or any other space race for that matter. Lets get some new weapons shall we?- Cylons didnt get enough screen time, IMO.  The "human" looking ones did but not the original, VERY cool cylons in their native robot form.- A little heavy on the sexual themes but it really didnt hurt anything. The "hottie" Cylon character was actully pretty creepy and completely untrustworthy. But still, there were a few overly sexual moments.Overall, this is a great miniseries/ 1st effort and certainly sets up a series pretty well.  Im going to watch more and see if it holds up and carries itself.Dont read too much into the super-negative reviews that are coming in from 40++ year olds that are mad that its not more like the original show. The original show had its moments but was cancelled pretty quickly...and NOT just for financial reasons. The original was all in all pretty dorky and had that "cheese whiz" fakeness in large doses... sorry but thats the deal on the old show. It looks HOPELESSLY dated and 70's-ish.I definitely recommended this first show or miniseries to any Sci-Fi fan.

reviewText: I had watched a few episodes of the original Battlestar Galactica TV series in the late 1970s, for two reasons: (1) It was the only sci-fi series on TV at the time, occurring as it did in the midst of the very long dry spell between Star Trek and Star Trek: The Next Generation. reviewText: Battlestar Galactica (2003 Miniseries) is just under three hours long making it an epic film, let alone groundbreaking television. It is available as part of Battlestar Galactica season one, so maybe you might get better value if you consider a broader purchase of the series. Battlestar Galactica (2003 Miniseries) is not the pilot. The pilot show is actually episode one of season one, but contains an opening `previously on...' to the Miniseries, so the Miniseries is mandatory Battlestar Galactica viewing. Essentially for the new Battlestar Galactica, start here.Battlestar Galactica (2003 Miniseries) is barely recognizable from the 1970s original series. Such is the scope of the makeover and development of the original storyline that all previous Battlestar Galactica series history has been declared void by the writers and the story has gone through a creative renewal. This reimagining was done to enhance the concept... and the reboot has paid off in aces.The Cylons were created by man. They evolved. There are many copies. And they have a plan. In the past, there was a war. The Cylons left Earth. Now they are back and they want revenge. They chase and try to kill the fleet across the galaxy.Battlestar Galactica has a lot of surprises in store. The story itself is kept tightly under wraps because there is a huge twist concerning the Cylons. Even the box covers are illusive.There is lots of powerhouse acting. Commander William Adama (Edward James Olmos) quickly becomes one of the most memorable characters in television history (you can rank him up there with the likes of Captain Picard). Laura Roslin (Mary McDonnell) slowly transcends into a pivotal character as catastrophes unfold. Starbuck is somebody very new and the role will amaze fans. Captain Lee 'Apollo' Adama (Jamie Bamber) brings a new breed of hero to the table and Dr. Gaius Baltar (James Callis) is the science geek with a secret to hide. Number Six (Tricia Helfer) will stun everybody with her looks and cold-blooded cruelty. Leoben Conoy (Callum Keith Rennie) is the con on the loose. Colonel Saul Tigh (Michael Hogan) is the second in command with a drinking problem and who has no qualms about venting his staff into space. Lt. Sharon 'Boomer' Valerii (Grace Park) is a pilot with a heart of gold dating Chief Petty Officer Galen Tyrol (Aaron Douglas) who does his best to make sure the ships are ready for launch and not blowing up in the service area. This is but a small section of the enormous cast that Battlestar Galactica has to offer. Expect lots of high-voltage drama in with the rapid paced action scenes.The CGI is impeccable with some of the biggest, fastest, more furious space battles since George Lucas. The fleet lead by the Galactica looks beautiful as they cruise through green glowing star clusters avoiding detection by the ever searching Cylons. The real stars of the show are the screenwriters. It is their boat and they are taking us on what appears to be a voyage unparallel to anything else you have seen before. When it comes to SF on TV, the makers of Battlestar Galactica are trying to actually match the superiority of Star Trek... and they are doing just that!

reviewText: Writing a review of the "Battlestar Galactica" miniseries may seem like a little bit of a cheat after having reviewed the complete series collection.  However, reviewing on this 3-hour epic that launched this ground-breaking science fiction series seems only proper."BSG" begins with the stunning introduction of the next generation of Cylon soldiers, lead by #6, a new humanoid Cylon (Tricia Helfer) who is an incredibly sexy blonde in a tight-fitting red dress.  After destroying the never-used armistice station on the 40th anniversary of the conclusion of the First Cylon War, these `children of mankind' begin their way towards the 12 Colonies of Kobol to launch an attack of extermination.Flash forward a short period of time and you get natural, genuine introduction to all the main players in the series.  Commander Adama is about to retire and is attending the decommissioning ceremony of the relic of the first war, the Battlestar Galactica;  Lee Adama is dealing with his bitter feelings towards his father; Secretary of Education, Laura Roslin has just been diagnosed with breast cancer; and perpetual drunken malcontents Saul Tigh and Kara Thrace get into a dust-up during a card game.  In addition, scientific genius, Gaius Baltar, is introduced living his decadent lifestyle with a woman who appears to be much more trouble than he bargained for.Against this backdrop, the most stunning attack in television (and, perhaps, cinematic) history begins.  The Cylons have set their Basestars above all 12 colonial worlds and launched countless nuclear warheads at the planets.  When the colonies try to mount a counter-attack, they find all their defenses inoperative due to some security breach.  Those humans who managed to escape the holocaust on the ground, and be aboard ships that were not impacted by the defense breach, make a desperate escape.Because scenes of the attack don't focus strictly on the bomb drops and space battles, but rather on the slow and brutal discovery by everyone of the scope of the attack, the impact is much more striking.  There are few scenes more gripping than Roslin's discovery that she is the highest ranking member of the government still alive, making her the new president.  The emotional swearing in takes its photographic inspiration from President Lyndon Johnson's own swearing in following JFK's assassination in 1963.The panic and very real fear of humanity's extermination draw the viewers into the series, emotionally, in a way that campy and comical 70's version of the show never could (indeed, it's pretty hard to even try to watch the original series after experience the re-imagined one).  The exodus of humanity from the charred remains of the 12 Colonies sets the table for the challenge, compelling and sometimes controversial journey that will follow.  Few shows have ever burst out of the gate this strongly.
