It's our first taste of the reimagining of the show, which has been hailed by many fans as not only one of the best shows on television, but as the best science fiction show of all time.  I've only seen the miniseries, so I can't really comment on the quality of the episodes that follow, but if it continues with the excellent writing, action, special effects, and directing, it just may live up to the hype.  The first scenes go by in a blur, introducing so many characters and so much history that I began to feel a bit of trepidation that I'd bought into the wrong kind of show, but by the time I was fifteen minutes into it, I realized that not only was I enthralled in the story, but I already knew who all of the characters were.  The writing is so subtle that it sucks you into the middle of events, and attentive viewers will hit the ground running, and enjoying every minute of it.  It's exciting, it's sad, it's meaty (at over three hours), and at it's most base, it's a story about humanity.  I'm definitely on for the ride.THE PACKAGEThis section has no impact on the rating, and pretty much just serves as a warning to viewers.  While the miniseries certainly stands on its own well enough... there is absolutely no reason to buy this.  If you're interested in getting into BATTLESTAR, just buy theSeason Oneset.  The miniseries is included in that set, along with an entire season of greatness.  So while the content of this DVD is exceptional, it would be best to pass on buying this separately and just go for the season set.8/10

reviewText: After being absent for 20 years, the cylons return.  Without a word, they attack humanity and begin a massive campaign of genocide.  Through espionage, sabotage and advanced technology, they have developed a method of deactivating all human ships and defense systems.  Humanity is completely helpless and is slaughtered without remorse.The only surviving ship is the Battlestar Galactica.  It's the oldest ship in the fleet.  Its disconnected, outdated networks and old, sturdy construction renders it immune to the Cylon's new form of electronic attack.  The Galactica and it's fleet of aging fighters prove to be able to put up a fight and secure the remnants of humanity as they flee from the destruction of the Cylons, proving that sometimes old dogs perform the best tricks.The miniseries takes us through these opening moves and introduces us to the characters that we'll follow through the series.This show is fantastic.  I can understand some purists not liking the changes, but the whole show is laid out to make a far more intriguing series.  As other reviewers have mentioned, this one isn't nearly as kid-friendly as the original series and this is highlighted by the show's time slot: 10pm EST.  This is a show aimed squarely for fans of the original, who grew up watching sci-fi and wondered where it all went, in the mess of modern reality shows and police dramas.The new series and the old series really only share one thing: the basic concept.  That's pretty much the extent of similarties though.Old cylons were big, shiney, stupid robots.  New cylons are either sleek, vicious shiney robots or cyborgs made to look like humans.  This makes the overall cylon threat much more menacing: they can look like people.  There are a limited number of human-looking models but we don't know what they all are, or who may turn out to be a cylon.  It adds a level of paranoia and intrigue to the new series that the old series simply couldn't generate.Purists definiately don't like the gender swapping of some of the characters (Starbuck is female in the new series) but it's fairly immaterial and I have to confess to liking that this show has a much better mix of male and female main characters.  The old show was a little too much Captain Kirk, if you know what I mean.  Incidentally, the original actor who played Apollo, while not in the miniseries, does show up as a significant character in season 1 of the show.The acting, effects, the uniforms, the lighting, the camera work, the ARTIFICIAL camera work done in the space shots, this show is absolutely amazing to watch, the miniseries in particular gives us some stunning displays.  Not since Firefly have I seen a TV show with special effects that were this good.  And it's no wonder, since the same special effects team was behind both shows (something to watch for if you're a Firefly fan -- in the scene where the president talks to the doctor, look at the ships flying by outside the window.  One of them is the Firefly...  Little easter egg for you.)This is sci-fi at its best and it's about time we got something this good going again.  A man can only take so much Star Trek.

reviewText: In my mind's eye, shortly after May 1977, a group of TV executives were positively apopleptic over the lack of sci-fi programming for the upcoming season.The parasites, I mean, TV execs must have screamed "Lucas created a (profanity) sensation and all I have are re-runs of William Shatner!"Somewhere, someone came up with the idea that eventually became "Battlestar Galactica."Now, if my memory serves me correctly, the show was popular with the young crowd, but the episodes were costly to produce; that was probably why the special effects were recycled about two dozen times per episode.The original show did not last long, and the fans were sad.--------- {:^( -----------------------------Now that someone in Hollywood has resurrected the series, reshaped it and did a damn good job, the die-hard fan base is apopleptic over the fact that the new show is not a scene-by-scene recreation of what they fell in love with as a kid.Tough luck I say. New Century, new idiots recycling old ideas.  This time around they improved the storyline, and made it more enjoyable to a wider base of fans.Personally, I am pleased w/ the miniseries, and the new series deserves to be more successful than the original.Here is my list of praises:@ The cast is superb; the actors selected are doing a great job, and I hope they all get signed on for another season.@ Tricia Helfer is THE reason why nerdy fan boys will stay home on Friday nights to watch the show.  However, in my opinion, she's too conservatively dressed.@ The Combat scenes are few, which makes me appreciate them more when I see them.@ The new Cylon Raiders are hot, and menacing.@ The Caprica storyline (from the series, the seed of which was planted in the mini) is interesting, as it keeps me tuning in every week.@ The Tin Cans/Toasters appear more menacing than the originals, but resemble them enough to bring back the memories.@ The shape of the Galactica > they did a good job on the design. It looks industrial enough; the Enterprise could not match this one in terms of "looking used."  (They must have taken a cue from George Lucas's "Industrialized Universe" which worked in suspending disbelief).@ The similarities between "the Colonies" and 21st Century California/Canada (I think some of the show was filmed in Vancouver) are tolerable, as filming a Sci-Fi show probably requires a sizeable budget. I don't want to see resources wasted on things like a Zandar Fruit, when apples are available.@The writing staff has tried to adhere to the laws of physics, at least more so than some other shows (but not as closely as '2001: Space Odyssey').@ The "Cylons-as-human" aspect makes for a great plot element, and I am dying to see where they go with this.@ The pervasive nature of the net GUARANTEES that fan opinions will be heard, and this is likely to improve the show in the future.Here's my list of gripes:@ I am not too crazy about the pilot uniforms, as they look like cut-up raincoats pasted together with crazy glue.@ The Vipers do not thrill me (neither the original nor the new Mark VI series).@The shuttles are also lackluster (but better than the originals).-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-One day, if I am ever a grandparent, most of my contemporaries will be nursing a broken heart over how the great grandson of Patrick Stewart "reimagines" the all-new Star Trek:TOS.Kirk is still Captain of the Enterprise, but now he's wear's an eye patch, has a parrot on his shoulder and channels for both Captian Hook and Blackbeard; Spock is now a cross-dressing woman who thinks she's a man and is torn apart over the illogic of it all; Sulu and Worff are related, but no one knows exactly how; Scotty is now a dog-human hybrid;  Uhura is portrayed by a Native American; Batman is a crew member and the Klingons all look like Ralph Kramden (it turns out he's their deity).  It may cause riots in the street, but it will probably be good television, or at least what would pass for it in the coming decades.All in all, 1978 it ain't, and we are in for one heck of a ride; I hope it don't jump the shark too soon.

reviewText: The original Battlestar Galactica series premiered on ABC when I was about 11 years old.  I watched the series religiously until its cancellation, and even watched the short-lived Galactica 1980, although I was extremely disappointed that Richard Hatch, Dirk Benedict, Herb Jefferson and Laurette Spang did not return for this series.  Now, after re-broadcasts on the SCI-FI Channel and separate attempts by Glen Larson and Richard Hatch to revive the show, Galactica is reborn as a miniseries and now a new weekly series on the SCI-FI Channel.  I missed the original broadcast of the miniseries, but did recently purchase the DVD.  I will admit I was pleasantly surprised.  The new Galactica is good, very good.  And in some ways, it is even superior to the original.  Several actors turn in some outstanding performances here, including Edward James Olmos as Commander William Adama, Mary McDonnell as President Laura Roslin, Jamie Bamber as Captain Lee "Apollo" Adama, as well as Katee Sackhoff as Lieutenant Kara "Starbuck" Thrace and Grace Park as Sharon "Boomer" Valerii.  The new Galactica has more of a backstory on the history between the Colonial humans and the Cylons, evoking themes from the Butlerian Jihad in the history from Frank Herbert's Dune universe and from Issac Asimov's robot novels.  I also love how the miniseries and new series have a much grittier feel for the Galactica universe.  As I write this review, it has been reported that the new BSG has already achieved something the original did not--a second season.  I'm already looking forward to Season Two.  While BSG purists might hate the new Galactica, I wholeheartedly recommend Battlestar Galactica: The Miniseries to new fans as well as to old fans with open minds.

reviewText: Let me be honest:  the miniseries of BATTLESTAR GALACTICA probably shouldn't receive a five-star rating.  But if you consider this as part of Season One as a whole, it definitely does.  Rumors had been circulating for years of a possible revival of the original series, but the actual show that we got exceeded all expectations.  The new series subtly updates the older series, retaining some characters (though sometimes with altered genders, such as Starbuck and Boomer) and spaceships and other elements, but definitely modernizing everything.  But the show does much more than that.  It also synthesizes aspects of a host of Sci-Fi shows that came after the end of the original BATTLESTAR GALATICA.  Astute fans of TV Sci-Fi will recognize a host of elements from prior shows.Series creator (recreator?) Ron Moore is the perfect individual to head a series that borrows liberally from all the best shows to come before.  He worked on such classic Sci-Fi series as STAR TREK: THE NEXT GENERATION, STAR TREK:  DEEP SPACE NINE, and ROSWELL, before heading up this project.  You can look at almost any major Sci-Fi series of the past twenty-five years and find a number of resemblances between this series and its predecessor.  For instance, take FIREFLY, which has exerted a massive influence on BATTLESTAR GALATICA.  The resemblance is not completely coincidental, in that most of the special effects people moved over from FIREFLY when that series was tragically cancelled.  (In fact, in the first scene in Caprica, where Mary McDonnell is told she has cancer, if you freeze frame the shots of the various spaceships flying overhead, you will see a Firefly-class cargo ship.)  The visual techniques perfected in FIREFLY have been taken over by BATTLESTAR GALATICA.  For instance, the use of zoom close ups and focusing that was originated in FIREFLY CGI work is a staple with this show.  Much of the physics of the spaceships has also been adopted as well as the lighting.  This show also comes very close to the "silence in space" aesthetic that caused FIREFLY so much grief with FOX studio heads (Joss Whedon and Co. insisted on silence for weapons firing in space, since with no atmosphere there can be no sound--BATTLESTAR GALATICA has sound, but it is minimal compared to other series).  Or take the very long tracking shots that were such an important part of FIREFLY.  On several occasions on FIREFLY the camera would follow a character from one to another part of Serenity, and our first introduction to Battlestar Galatica is through a very long establishing shot, starting with Starbuck as she jobs through the ship and ending up with Commander Adama.  Sometimes the borrowings from other series are minimal, such as Number 6, whose name was borrowed from the great sixties series THE PRISONER and whose metaphysics was largely drawn from the "Harvey" version of Scorpius from FARSCAPE.  Or the series' goal of traveling to earth, which is similar to the main thing driving the plot of STAR TREK:  VOYAGER.  Almost every element of BATTLESTAR GALATIC feels borrowed from another source, whether the aforementioned shows or STARSHIP TROOPERS.  This isn't bad:  it is like a avid Sci-Fi fan has just gone wonderfully crazy in harvesting the best from a horde of previous great shows.Like the original series, this one presents a military structure (I actually prefer nonmilitary series, like FARSCAPE and FIREFLY, in which the main characters are civilians or, at most, veterans).  But unlike most other series, there is a wonderful tension between the military and civilian factions.  Interestingly, for the most part we are supposed to side with the civilians, though we are supposed to like the military as well, the only show I know with such a structure.The situation of the show is the classic one of humans versus machines, a conflict that goes back to the earliest days of Sci-Fi, from Fritz Lang's METROPOLIS to Jack Williams's great novel THE HUMANOIDS to 2001: A SPACE ODYSSEY.  As with other elements of the show, there is very little original here, with one exception.  This has to do not with the constitution of the show, but its tone.  This is a dark, bleak show.  If the STAR TREK shows were persistently utopian, this series is unquestionably dystopian.  And the mood of the series matches that.  Bad, awful, ugly things happen on this show.  For instance, in the miniseries at one point Number 6 breaks the neck of an infant in its stroller.  Later we know that a young girl playing with a doll is seconds from death.  The show's producers are not afraid to stick the knife in and then twist it a few times.  TV Sci-Fi has never been this unremittingly despairing.  The mood and bleakness of BATTLESTAR GALATICA makes for wonderful viewing for those not expecting all their TV to be happy, but I understand that many do not like their Sci-Fi quite so dark as this.Still, the miniseries, though it introduces one of the finest Sci-Fi series in the history of TV, isn't quite up to the level of the rest of the series.  Part of the reason is that a substantial portion of the show is spent introducing us to the main characters, establishing their interrelationships, and setting up the larger situation between the humans and the Cyclons.  As a result, one often feels in the miniseries that not a great deal is happening.  Once things start moving, it gets very exciting indeed, but it is a tad slow to get off the ground.  Some of the battle scenes rank with some of the best ever seen either on TV on in theaters.  In fact, with CGI becoming less and less expensive and more and more capable, we are in the new Golden Age of TV Sci-Fi, with TV shows capable of competing with the movies in special effects.All in all, this is the most delightful revival of a Sci-Fi series in the history of TV, unless one considers START TREK: THE NEXT GENERATION a revival of the original (and until that moment so many Sci-Fi fans yearn for, a revival of FIREFLY).  Anyone watching only the miniseries and not caring for it needs to understand that the series that follows is much, much better.  It is definitely an example of TV Sci-Fi at its finest.
summary: The opening episodes in one of the great revivals in TV history

reviewText: Having grown up with the original, like so many others, I did try to approach this mini-series with an open mind.  In fact, I tried to view this from the perspective of it being a completely new sci-fi saga divorced from any original.  Well, unfortunately, this new Galactica is really just a huge, unoriginal, disapointing mess.The principle problem with the Battlestar Galacica miniseries is that it seems to get too bogged down with far too many characters to reasonably keep up with... and characters would come along who you think might be essential to the story, then, no, they get left on a planet or blown up in space.  The show also seems to focus a little to hard on the human drama, forgetting that BG is and was at it's core supposed to be an all-ages kids show (wasn't it?)  But then they needed to revamped it for a more adult audience? (or are the uncomfortably graphic love scenes involving the 'Species'-ish cylon actress supposed to be aimed at kids?  I hope not!)Watching this pilot, there seemed to be so many elements inspired from other sources, that throughout the film you find yourself saying "oh, this is like Aliens, or this is like T3, or this is like Atari's 'Missle Command'..." etc.  For instance, at one point in the film Adama thinks that his son has died, and looks shocked and grief-stricken.  I was half-expecting him to try to sit down but miss the chair then mutter "Cylon b*stards, you've killed my son!".  Too many moments like this.  Here are some more observations:- By far one of the most troubling characters was the unnecessarily revamped Starbuck, who looks and sounds like a butch, tough-yet-unhealthy-looking version of Tasha Yar from ST:TNG.  Could they have made this character any more surly and unappealing?  Alright, I am comparing to the original BG here, but Starbuck was THE character that most 7-yr old boys like myself back then identified with: he was cool, witty and heroic.  The way that this new Starbuck provoked the John McCain-lookalike guy seemed completely uncalled for.  It wasn't funny, it wasn't very noble, and it made this Starbuck seem more colder and more difficult to associate with.  This new Starbuck: unlikeable and troubling.  This was one thing they really should not have redesigned.- The cylon ships: are these revamped Batman batwings from the first Batman film?  And where were the cylons in this movie?  They had so little screen time, when originally, they were one of the coolest things about the show (their voices too.)  Instead, now we have human-looking cylons, very reminiscent of Terminator (obviously) but also vaguely reminiscent of the tv show remake of War of the Worlds (where is Ironhorse when you need him?)- The music: extremely unmemorable and disapointing.  Ok, another comparison to the original BG, I'm sorry, but the original had a stirring, triumphant military theme.  This show:  I can barely recall the music, other than some annoying drums during a battle scene.- The ship interior: it was very hard to get the feeling that stuff taking place in a ship that was actually out in space.  It seemed more like watching stuff take place inside a ground-based army fortress as opposed to something out in space.  The only reminder of the space aspect was the vipers launching out.  Otherwise, this looks like this could have been a ground fortress.  Sure, it's a huge ship, but the illusion of space wasn't there.  Too much of the ship also looked like studio set.- Mary McDonnell's character - the miniseries focused just a little too much on her and could have given us more time for Galactica-specific characters.  Plus, Mary's hair... I'm sorry, but there comes a time when you give gracefully to age and let the natural gray through.  I don't mean this to be mean... I'm just saying that hair coloring of her magnitude just doesn't look realistic, and unfortunately ends up as a distracting feature for this character (maybe it's just me)- But some positive notes:  The SFX aren't bad in this, and it was good to see the old Viper ships in action again.  That was cool (but why do their weapons have to sound so lame?)  And Edward James Olmos as Castillo, I mean, Adama, was a good casting call.  Honestly, his character and dialog delivered in his deadplan, ultra-serious manner, was like seeing his Castillo character of 'Miami Vice' in a sci-fi environment.  As a huge a fan of Vice, this was a neat element of the show.  If only Jan Hammer could have written the score...But overall, I just can't recommend this.  It was somewhat interesting, just for the novelty of seeing BG again, but ultimately the show was messy and disapointing.

reviewText: Love or hate the original, this show is a wholly different animal.Yes, there are decided similarities in names and basic premise between this incredible human drama and the entertaining Star Wars rip-off that (older) die-hard SF fans know. There are also major differences.Foe example, a great deal has been made of the fact that Starbuck is now a female. SO WHAT?!?It's real simple. If you're looking for an exact duplication of the earlier TV show, you'll be disappointed. If you're looking for an intelligent, all-too-human SF drama of the highest possible quality, you'll be delighted.There are respectful nods to the original, but that's about as far as it goes. And, for this reviewer, that is plenty.I enjoyed the original series, but even then, and even as a special-effects oriented teen and an unabashed SF geek at the time, I realized that the original BG was not great drama and not even great SF. It was (and this is not intended as an insult to the artists who made the original, although it may sound otherwise) an opportunistic show capitalizing on the popularity of the original Star Wars by appealing to an audience that was, at that time, hungry for more Star Wars when none was available.The new series offer the best special effects that modern technology can offer... disparaging remarks about "shaky cam" from the ignorant and unenlightened aside. But beyond that it offers a very deep, often disturbing exploration of what it means to be human.The producers and writers of the new Battlestar Galactica have given us a whole new vision of the same basic premise: colonies of humans have been established on far distant planets. have evolved into wholly separate entities with different cultures,  and having long since lost touch with Earth. They are at war - and are losing - with a race named the Cylons, and are seeking the almost mythical Earth as a refuge.Perhaps that what made the original BG such a strong series despite it's painfully obvious attempt at being a Star Wars rip-off. The basic premise allows for an incredibly rich and powerful human drama to emerge. It's too bad that the original medium was network television of 20-some odd years ago; perhaps otherwise the concept could have been explored deeper back then.As it is, while the original series gave us sometimes touching but often illogical and always superficial pap dressed up with (what at the time passed for) excellent special effects,  this new series is looking into the very depths of the human psyche and the human soul. The special effects, while brilliant - astonishing, even. - are given second billing, which is precisely as it should be.I have deliberately and with malice aforethought :) withheld any semblance of a true spoiler form this review. Buy the damn DVD and watch this amazing show for yourself. It is well worth the money and time.
summary: Perhaps the best SF show to date

reviewText: I enjoyed it, but it's still a flick/show that you've got to give a chance to. This re-imagining (or re-boot, or re-make, or whatever) of the classic 70's show goes back to the beginning of the classic ancestor's roots.  After a dramatic pause between a generation's-old war between mankind and the robotic Cylons, the Cylons strike back and bring man to the brink of extinction.  With the twelve homeworlds of mankind rendered uninhabitable, the few remaining thousands gather in a ragtag fleet of spacecraft in search of the mythical 13th world of Earth.The miniseries junked much of what was campy, and brought in an air of unrelenting grimness.  But it also brought in a tight script with an overriding and irresistible theme: the Cylons are apparently superior to mankind in numbers and technology, and may be just a whole lot smarter as well.  Aliens in the original show, Cylons are revealed as man's creation here.  The "walking toasters" of 1978 are history - literally, you'll never forget an early scene shot in one of the Colonial War museums; the Galactica itself is portrayed as something of a relic, like one of those old warships turned into a museum - if you.  The show works on surprisingly thin characters - the politicians and soldiers have very little depth; this works because the script writes their shallowness into the story.  These aren't really thin characters; only very well done characterizations of thin people.  (My personal fave is Baltar - the treasonous villain portrayed to great effect by John Colicos in the original is depicted here as a manipulated sap; renowned by humans as one of the great minds of mankind, he remains one step ahead of those who might reveal his treachery; just how far Baltar has fallen into the Cylon camp remains one of the constant plot-lines of the first season.)  The direction is stylish in ways you wouldn't expect from a sci-fi show, or even most shows - made clear in an early scene that follows a cross-section of Galactica in a single, unbroken shot ala "Touch of Evil".  The decision to re-cast Boomer and Starbuck as women was gutsy and, I think, successful (and arguably safe - you won't have to re-think your favorite characters from the original at all).  The scripts are clever and, if nothing else, give our heroes something more than "Star Trek: The Next Generation" style technobabble.  (We're clued into the screenplay's sophistication during a card game occurring early in the film; there's just so much said between Starbuck and Col. Tigh that doesn't come out in their lines - thankfully).  I wasn't interested in the new BSG when it first came out - disinterest I'm now making up for.  If anything, this is the perfect salve for sci-fi fans left in the cold by similar recent re-imaginings of "Star Trek".

reviewText: Most reviews of this movie/miniseries will inevitably compare it to the original of the late 1970s.  Let's not go there.  This is much, MUCH better, and should be considered on its own merits.  A well-written story, well acted by a mix of familiar and new faces, with good directing and editing resulting in real tension and military drama, not merely cheesy space opera.  And with the current technology, it would have been easy to create an over-done, too-loud, explosion-packed extravaganza aimed at appealing to 14 year-old boys --- but they DIDN'T.To give you a feeling for the depth here... There is a interesting moment well into the story.  The Cylons have already wiped out the 12 colonies, leaving only a fleet of miscellaneous space vehicles under the leadership of the newly sworn-in President, formerly the Secretary of Education (whom Commander Adama sarcastically refers to as a "school teacher")... this fleet has just met up with the Galactica at a hidden weapons depot.  Madam President and Commander Adama are having their first private conversation, when she asks him:"Are you planning a military coup?"He pretends to be surprised by this question.  He was obviously considering this possibility, but now realizes that she is shrewd... not merely a party functionary or desk-bound bureaucrat.  She can see that he was considering this.  His actions throughout the story up to this moment indicate he was considering assuming political control, should the need arise. reviewText: When I first heard the name of this show, it did not sound promising.  I would have responded to a name like "Rocketship Milkyway" in much the same way.  It was undeniably suggestive of a fifties space drama.  I had also seen on occasion a seventies movie that seemed of questionable quality at my local library.  Then, mention of robot cylons rebelling against humanity did little more to further my interest.  I sighed to myself wondering why the robots must always turn on humanity, wreaking devastation with unstoppable steel limbs.Then I actually sat down and watched some episodes with my friends.  Truly the same general plot can be retold in a unique and startling way.  Most shows and movies with a similar theme do little more than testify against the horrors of science combined with the hubris of mortal men.  It seems to have been just the same since Frankenstein was first published up to the present.  Finally comes the latest remake of Battlestar Galactica, a show which shuns simple vilification of the robot rebels and for once closely examines what makes a sentient being human.  This is one of few shows I've seen of any genre that both entertains and provokes thought at the same time.  I find the co-existence of philosophy and steamy interludes rather to my liking.  Sexed up sci-fi doesn't always add to a show, but neither does the chaste uptightness of the Federation Star Fleet that stays in place despite all the provocative, form fitting uniforms.  In this case, I would say the sensual scenes are well done and are integrally related to the story.The acting in this new Battlestar Galactica is superb.  The writers of the show included human flaws in their characters, eliminating the squeaky clean boyscout personalities that tend to  dominate the decks of starships.  The cast of this show includes some big names and delivers an inspired performance.  The dark, realistic atmosphere is appropriate, as humans are in a situation of urgent duress.  The consistently imaginative story won me over, a viewer who was at first quite skeptical.  To say the least, the creators obviously thought through this operation carefully.Even small things about this show excite me.  For example, a sci-fi franchise that completely does away with energy weapons and laser guns.  They actually use shells and nukes in space.  This would seem for the most part intuitive but is rarely implemented.My surprise at the brilliance of this television program augments  my anticipation for the next season.  Surely this new attempt will be longer lived than the original, quickly canceled sequence of 17 episodes.  I wholly recommend it to all!

reviewText: 40 years after the Cylon War, humanity and the robotic race they created have reached a diffcult peace. When the Cylons develop a very human looking model, they use them to invade the government and the military obtaining defense codes. In a surprise attack during the decommission ceremony for the Galatica, the Cylons short circut humanity's defenses and use nuclear devices to bomb the 12 colonies before adding geneocide to their crimes. Humanity clearly isn't completely innocent either; while they created the Cylons they treated their robots as slave labor. When the robot revolt humanity not only tried to defend itself but made every effort to try and erdicate the Cylons as well. The Galatica along with its ragtag fleet of military and civilian space vessels are now trying to outrun the Cylons headed for a legendary planet settled by humanity--Earth.When writer/producer Ron Moore ("Star Trek: First Contact", "Deep Space Nine", "Carnivale")decided to revisit the concept from Glen Larson's original TV series he elected to do some major overhauling for a contemporary audience. He changed Starbuck into a woman (good move, it actually works very well), complicated Adama's relationship with his son Apollo (son blames father for his brother's death)and creates a Cylon truly worth fearing; they're no longer just "walking toasters" they appear human but still have the souls of automatons.I understand that fans of the original series aren't very happy with this updated, darker spin on the same tale. I think it's terrific. Edward James Olmos brings a sense of humanity to Adama and the rest of the cast (particularly Katte Sackhoff as Lt. Kara 'Starbuck' Thrace, Mary McDonnell as the initially reluctant President, Jamie Bamber as Captain Lee 'Apollo' Adama, Tricia Helfer as Number 6 and British actor James Callis as Dr. Gaius Balter the unwitting architect of humanity's destruction)are truly spectacular bringing depth and nuance to their roles.The visuals are truly stunning (although a couple of CGI shots are so-so). Moore's background in the military clearly helped as this is probably the most convincing (this side of "Aliens")portrayal of a spacefaring military ship and crew I've seen. Moore provided some of the best scripts for "Star Trek: The Next Generation", "Deep Space Nine", "Roswell", "Carnvale" and "Touching Evil". His feature films include "Star Trek: Generations", "First Contact" and the story for "Mission: Impossible II". He focuses much more on the dramatic elements of the original series and character than the space opera elements and that brings a much needed humanity to this series.I'm puzzled by comments about a second disc--the version I purchased of this was 1 dual sided disc with the feature film stunningly transferred onto a dual layered side (along with an intelligent commentary from the director Michael Rymer and writer/producer Moore)and with deleted scenes and a featurette on the other side of the disc. To the DVD producers credit, they ask original star Richard Hatch his opinion of the series (he doesn't like some the liberities taken)and there's fair balance provided for both sides of the argument. Hatch does appear in during the first season of the series but, of course, not as Apollo.Pay close attention to the little details in the film. The Serenity from "Firefly" makes a cameo. An original costume and Viper along with a model of a Cylon base station also appear. Also, the man we see in the first few minutes that meets Number 6 (a witty reference to "The Prisoner" as well)at the beginning is actually the father of the Boxey character introduced much later in the mini-series. Moore also wanted a sense of reality to the series so he chose elements that you might see on a real military vessel today such as the phones used to communicate on the ship (with cords!)and a decided "retro" look borrowed from the 21st century with some equipment.Best Buy will be offering the first season (as released in the UK although adapted for US Region 1 players)exclusively in July for a limited period of time. Fair warning, however, is that the Best Buy set has a different opening theme song and only deleted scenes. None of the planned extras that appear on that set will appear on the US set. There aren't any commentary tracks or other extras on the UK set so if you're into the extras, the UK adapted set is not the one to get. I however, plan on purchasing it anyway as I already have the pilot separately. The mini-series pilot will also be a part of the US set with the extras relocated (from what I'm told) to a separate disc set.  Oh and just a reminder to folks that get overheated about the original "BSG" and this remake--it's only a TV show folks!

reviewText: Whenever I see reviews of the Battlestar Galactica Miniseries that claim that it is mediocre and/or ruining a good thing, I've noticed that they have been penned by those who refer to themselves as "pure" fans of the original series. For those of you who would prefer to ignore the peanut gallery, this review provides the neccesary information.Ok. So, there is this three-hour miniseries that re-imagines an old show. In truth, some of the backstory is retained, but much of it is scrapped and rewritten to an older, more mature audience. This is essentially a pilot for a longer TV series that has already completed its first-season run by the time you read this review. What the miniseries is not trying to do is to undermine the genre, or its fans for that matter. This very crisp and new docu-styled film is more than that. The writers wanted not only to revive an old idea, but also to revisit a genre that has become much less popular as society has matured. BSG is not for a family audience. The material presented can be described as intellectually provocative and also allegorical. Politics plays a  part in this new series. Human themes such as nuclear paranoia, sex, and politics, are not thrown around lightly. The issues carry some weight of their own, which makes the new BSG a drama first and placing sci-fi in the second tier. A good move I must say.Even though the miniseries has its good traits, there are many flaws that hold me back from giving it four stars. As a pilot, it succeeds to set the atmosphere but it does nothing in actually analyzing the events that take place within the miniseries itself. And although that new dramatic shift makes watching it much more bearable, the length and some cheesy sci-fi undertones still seep through. But, if you have three hours and an open mind, you might enjoy the new BSG, or you may not. It all depends on how patient you are. For those of you who would rather enjoy something more fast-paced, check the first season DVD when it comes out.

reviewText: When most TV shows hit the airwaves, they struggle to make it an entire season and hope to find themselves along the way. Suffice it to say, though, that you don't have to have ANY prior knowledge to get sucked into the plot.Overall, this 3-hour miniseries sets the stage for the Sci-Fi Channel TV series, proving that shows ending in "Trek" or beginning with "Star" don't necessarily corner the market on sci-fi fare.
